repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Accountability for Decentralization
            in the Social Sectors Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Accountability for
            Decentralization in the Social Sectors Technical Assistance
            Project for Peru were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: during the past years, the Bank
            has systematically invested efforts in promoting operations
            with multiple sub-executing units. This has been based on
            the documented evidence about how inter-institutional
            coordination supports the attainment of common goals.
            Results, however, have been rather ambiguous. On the one
            hand, institutions have partially coordinated their
            activities as a consequence of external pressure imposed on
            them. On the other, however, communication and information
            flow has not yet been institutionalized and only takes place
            if there is an external facilitator promoting it. Thus, the
            cost-effectiveness of such efforts has not yet proved to be
            positive since they turn out to be extremely demanding in
            terms of time, resources and energy. In sum,
            inter-institutional coordination cannot be promoted from a
            top-down approach. It rather needs to be part of a bottom-up
            strategy that departs from the sectors themselves.
            Experience shows that project technical staffs usually lack
            time to coordinate. In addition, when they submit documents
            (i.e., terms of reference, proposal, deliverables) to the
            Bank they usually press for immediate approval which takes
            longer than expected provided the Bank has further
            observations and recommendations. Based on these facts, as
            part of Social Technical Assistance Lending (TAL)
            implementation, the Bank promoted a technical coordination
            space with participation of all relevant actors. This
            facilitated discussion, feedback and informal approval of
            outputs in order to expedite the administrative procedures.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Accountability for Decentralization
            in the Social Sectors Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Accountability for Decentralization in the Social Sectors
            Technical Assistance Project, is to strengthen
            results-oriented, and participatory planning, including
            monitoring and evaluation, emphasizing on decentralized
            social programs at the Ministry for Women and Social
            Development - MIMDES. The first component will improve the
            quality of social policies and programs, taking into account
            the issue of decentralization, whether already
            decentralized, or subject to future decentralization;
            whereas the second component will implement Performance
            Agreements and Accreditation of social sectors, by ensuring
            adequate decentralization of the social programs, through
            the design, and implementation of the instruments for the
            accreditation process, particularly for social programs;
            implementing performance, and/or management agreements
            (PAS); and, by monitoring and evaluating budget transfers to
            sub-national governments. The third component aims at
            improving monitoring and evaluation (M&E) in the Social
            Sectors. The purpose of this component is to build M&E
            capacity by strengthening existing monitoring instruments,
            and establishing new ones as necessary, and strengthening
            analytical capacity among the different actors engaged in
            the implementation process.
